ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:

options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learnt to write, read, listen, and speak basic Spanish and learnt about Spanish culture.
This course was a great introduction to Spanish.
basic present and past tense in soanish

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength - lots of participation during class
Weakness - a lot of homework, and many quizzes and assignments

This course required me to practice my Spanish often as there were assignments every day and constantly new things to be studying but I feel that this was to my benefit. I usually felt prepared for my tests and I never felt like I had to cram to study anything. The pacing can feel a little intense sometimes but ultimately the course was forgiving when it needed to be and I did not have any problems nor did I fall behind. A weakness that I could see is that this class would be very hard to catch back up with if one where to fall behind though I am not sure how that could be remedied without taking away what makes this class successful to begin with.
strengths - 3 synchronized classes and 2 asynchronous classes, helped with concentration and engagement

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Since this class was a small seminar, I do not think that the class was very different than how it would be in person. Not meeting on zoom every morning and giving us some days to just study and learn on our own was nice. I do feel like it was a little bit hard to engage in conversation (in Spanish) with my classmates though we were given some time to do so.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you want to have a foundational knowledge of Spanish.

Yes. I had heard that this class is very intimidating but if you make sure that you regularly keep up with your work, do all of your assignments, and practice then it will not be too bad. It is a challenging course but if you want to learn Spanish, you will learn a lot over the course of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
